article_title: Premiums going up for many health plans in 2015
article_text:
Premiums going up for many health plans in 2015 Buyers get more choices

Photo: Associated Press File Photo HealthCare.gov is the federal exchange set up under ACA for people... Premiums for individual and small-group health insurance products sold in Texas will go up an average of 4 percent come Jan. 1, a San Antonio Express-News analysis of federal data shows.

To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to ExpressNews.com. SIGN IN

article_metadata.description: The data, released by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, focuses on health plans sold to consumers shopping for their own coverage and small employers providing health insurance to workforces of fewer than 50 full-time employees.  “There may be new players in the market who can offer a better deal, even a new product,” said Anne Dunkelberg, associate director of the health and wellness program at the Center for Public Policy Priorities, a Texas public advocacy group.  Humana is enacting what amounts to the state’s largest rate boost across a single product line — an average increase of 24 percent for HumanaOne EPOx individual major medical coverage sold only in Hidalgo County, federal data show.  Humana told HHS that rate calculations for all of its Texas plans are affected by many factors, including changes to contracts with hospitals and physicians, shifts in expected claims costs and changes in the use of medical services.  “Our premium rates for 2015 reflect many changing factors in the marketplace — for instance, the growing use of high-cost specialty drugs, increasing or decreasing numbers of people with chronic health conditions or medical needs, and the increasing (or decreasing) cost of medical services,” Humana said in a prepared statement to the Express-News.  During the last enrollment period, only 17 people purchased Community First health plans on the exchange because the prices far exceeded those of competing products.  “We have a history and expertise in the individual medical market — it’s our primary focus — and we believe our pricing is appropriate due to our broad network offering and the overall marketplace risk,” an Assurant Health spokesperson said in a prepared statement.  Because Assurant Health believes consumers should have flexibility to access the doctors and health care providers of their choice, we sell PPO individual major medical plans exclusively.  The new rates reflect the company’s assessment of the market and overall costs, including market risk and the influx of new customers who previously lacked coverage, the spokesperson said.  Humana’s San Antonio HMOx individual major medical plans, sold both on and outside of the exchange, will see an average rate increase of 16 percent across the product line, as will the company’s HMOx plans in the Houston, Austin and Waco markets.  The rates that health insurers currently charge vary based on several factors, including medical care costs for a region and pharmaceutical cost and utilization. …
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O'Hare, Staff Writer
